paper_metadata.title:
Towards Sustainable Grinding 
of Difficult -to-Cut Alloys—A Holistic Review 
and Trends

machine_info.material_processed: 45-gauge steel, DZ125 superalloy, Ti-6Al-4V alloy, K4125 and Inconel718 nickel-based superalloys, stainless steel

energy_data.power_consumption: grinding power ranges from 1.1 to 1.2 kW; the power consumed by coolant delivery rises from 0.2 up to 7.8 kW; and the power lost caused by the coolant increases from 0.2 up to 3.2 kW

kpi_metrics.specific_energy_consumption: the specific energy of hard turning of 4319 steel with 60 HRC is under 10 J/mm3, while the specific energy of grinding the same material ranges from 40 to 90 J/mm3
kpi_metrics.efficiency: Product Sustainability Index (PSI) of grinding with MQL is 46.06% more sustainable
other_kpis: MQL machining has the potential to save up to 15% of the cost.

additional_notes: This paper provides a holistic review of sustainability in grinding difficult-to-cut alloys, encompassing current trends and future directions, focusing on reducing hazardous coolant, energy consumption, and carbon emissions.
